admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall achievement of the project
            objectives is satisfactory, and sustainability is likely.
            Both World Bank and Borrower performances are rated as
            satisfactory. Lessons learned include the following: 1)
            Flexibility during implementation enhances reaching
            outcome-oriented development objectives. The combination of
            outcome orientation, flexible project design, and timely
            repsonse to the implementation issues saved significant cost
            and time while maintaining an effective development impact
            on the ground. 2) Capacity building and commitment to
            infrastructure asset preservation require sustained
            involvement over time. An incremental transport sector
            approach--based on a series of rehabilitation projects with
            increased focus on maintenance and important capacity
            building components--has proved to be effective. 3) Contract
            management and timely handling of contractual disputes are
            critical to attaining high quality infrastructure.
            Construction defects were detected and corrected during the
            construction phase. Additional defects appeared during the
            Defect Liability Period. Fiedl investigations and intensive
            studies to identify the causes, extent, and liability of
            defects were carried out by an independent consultant, local
            consultants, and the Ministry of Communication, Transport,
            and Post and Construction (MTCPC). Subsequently, with the
            Bank's support, MCTPC was able to reach an amicable
            settlement with the contractor, and the estimated liability
            was apportioned among the parties
